name: Nvidia
title: Bloom Energy Is Outperforming Nvidia As It Seizes The AI Moment
description:
Analysts see Bloom Energy, and its growing capacity, as a major player in powering data centers amid an expected energy shortfall.
Capitalizing On AI Data Center Deals In 2025, Bloom Energy inked major deals with Brookfield Asset Management (BAM), Oracle and the data center company Equinix (EQIX).
Bloom Energy successfully delivered volumes to its first Oracle site within 55 days of the deal announcement vs. a 90-day target commitment.
Bloom Energy Stock Performance Propelled by these deals, Bloom Energy stock surged nearly 300% last year.
Analysts' Take On Bloom Energy Following American Electric Power's key regulatory filing, Clear Street raised its price target on Bloom Energy to 68 from 58, keeping a hold rating on shares.
text:
Renewable energy and power supplier Bloom Energy (BE) is up almost 70% in the young 2026 stock market and has galloped more than 420% in the last 12 months, outperforming Nvidia (NVDA), Oracle (ORCL) and other Big Tech artificial intelligence plays.

Investors see Bloom's solid oxide fuel cell as a robust source of power for the surging energy demand caused by the expansion of AI data centers. Bloom's cells operate independently of traditional power grids. They are also highly efficient, emitting only heat and clean water, according to the company.

↑ X NOW PLAYING How The AI Arms Race Is Redefining The Energy Sector In 2026

In its earlier iterations Bloom Energy was viewed as a green energy company, with promising tech, but it struggled with the same skepticism from investors as other climate stocks. However, the continued proliferation of AI has seen it find a new source of demand for its fuel cells.

Now, Bloom Energy is rapidly scaling its manufacturing capacity from 1 gigawatt currently to two gigawatts by the end of 2026, with its existing footprint capable of holding up to five gigawatts of capacity. Analysts see Bloom Energy, and its growing capacity, as a major player in powering data centers amid an expected energy shortfall.

"The company is viewed as an attractive, highly reliable time-to-power solution that will drive rapid volume growth, offering one of the fastest paths to power with the lowest execution risk for AI and data center customers," Morgan Stanley analysts noted on Jan. 18.

Bloom Energy did not respond to a request for comment.

Accelerating Profit Growth On These Tailwinds

In late October, the San Jose, Calif.,-based fuel cell manufacturer easily topped third-quarter earnings as revenue swelled 57% vs. a year earlier to $519 million. Adjusted earnings were 15 cents a share vs. a 1-cent loss a year earlier.

Bloom Energy is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings and revenue in early February. Analysts forecast earnings declining 30% to 30 cents per share with sales totaling $647.3 million, up 13.2% vs. a year ago, according to FactSet. However, for the full year, Bloom Energy profit is predicted to grow 93% to 54 cents a share with revenue increasing 30% to $1.91 billion.

"This seminal year for Bloom positions us for an even stronger 2026 and beyond, with higher growth and more profitability," Bloom Energy founder and Chief Executive KR Sridhar said on the Oct. 28 third-quarter earnings call.

Stocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth Stocks

Sridhar added there are three major tailwinds that Bloom is benefiting from today that have "created a once-in-a-generation opportunity for us to become the global standard for on-site power generation."

The CEO said these tailwinds are the AI buildout, federal policy that is pushing the U.S. to win the AI race and the fact that Bloom Energy's product innovation is "advancing at a pace more akin to semiconductor evolution than to that of traditional industrial products."

"Bloom is now positioned to become the standard in on-site power, which many of us believe will be a $1 trillion market," Sridhar said.

With this backdrop, analysts expect Bloom Energy's 2026 earnings to soar 293% compared to 2024 levels. Through 2030, the Street view has annual profit growing at a steady pace, hitting $6.36 per share at the beginning of the next decade.

Capitalizing On AI Data Center Deals

In 2025, Bloom Energy inked major deals with Brookfield Asset Management (BAM), Oracle and the data center company Equinix (EQIX).

In October, Bloom Energy announced that Brookfield Asset Management will invest up to $5 billion to deploy its fuel cells at AI data centers. Bloom Energy and Brookfield are actively collaborating on the design and delivery of AI factories globally. Brookfield is one of the world's largest AI infrastructure investors and has already invested $50 billion in AI opportunities while tripling the size of its AI strategy over the next three years.

Best IBD 50 Stocks To Watch

CEO Sridhar says Bloom Energy will be the preferred on-site provider for Brookfield's infrastructure portfolio of AI factories, data center operators, corporate facilities and other factories.

The announcement with Brookfield came after Bloom Energy cut a deal in late July with Oracle to supply fuel cell technology for that hyperscaler's AI data centers. Bloom Energy successfully delivered volumes to its first Oracle site within 55 days of the deal announcement vs. a 90-day target commitment.

Bloom Energy Stock Performance

Propelled by these deals, Bloom Energy stock surged nearly 300% last year. Through Jan. 23, Bloom shares have soared 66.7% in the 2026 stock market, leading the way in Investor's Business Daily's Energy-Alternative/Other industry group. The group's 54 stocks have collectively advanced 9.2% so far in 2026, good for 83rd out of the 197 industry groups ranked by IBD.

Bloom Energy is currently trading near record highs and is just below a buy zone from a cup base with a traditional 147.86 buy point, according to MarketSurge charts.

In the past 12 months, dating back to Jan. 23, 2025, Bloom Energy is up almost 424%. For comparison, in that time frame Nvidia is up 27.5% while Oracle has fallen 5%. Fellow Big Tech hyperscalers Microsoft (MSFT) and Amazon.com (AMZN) are up 4.3% and 1.6, respectively, since Jan. 23, 2025.

Bloom Energy stock has a perfect 99 Composite Rating. The AI data center energy play also has a 99 Relative Strength Rating and an 80 EPS Rating.

"We have strong traction across all channels of the AI ecosystem," Sridhar said on the third-quarter earnings call. "As we continue to penetrate new geographies and verticals, success builds upon itself and should make each new market entry easier than the first. The opportunity is vast and we are still in the early innings."

Bloom Energy Starts 2026 With A Bang

The strong Bloom stock move to start 2026 comes as a Wyoming data center project won a key approval earlier this month.

Laramie County commissioners on Jan. 6 reportedly approved site plans for a 1.8-gigawatt data center in Wyoming. Morgan Stanley analyst David Arcaro wrote on Jan. 8 that the proposed project includes 900 megawatts of power generated by fuel cells, with Bloom Energy named as the potential fuel cell provider.

Clean Energy Stock Up 410% In 2025 Jumps After Earnings Beat

The project is expected to start construction in the first quarter of 2026. Arcaro said that 900 megawatts would equate to around $3 billion in product revenue for Bloom Energy vs. the expected 2025 product revenue of $1.45 billion.

Importantly, an unregulated subsidiary of American Electric Power (AEP) executed an unconditional purchase agreement on Jan. 4 to acquire a substantial portion of its option for solid oxide fuel cells to develop and construct a fuel generation facility for about $2.65 billion, according to an AEP regulatory filing. The filing showed there is a 20-year offtake agreement with a "high investment grade third party consumer" for 100% of the output of the fuel cell generation facility planned for Cheyenne.

American Electric Power previously partnered with Bloom Energy to deploy up to 1 gigawatt of Bloom's solid oxide fuel cell generators, primarily to power Amazon Web Services data centers.

Analysts' Take On Bloom Energy

Following American Electric Power's key regulatory filing, Clear Street raised its price target on Bloom Energy to 68 from 58, keeping a hold rating on shares. The firm noted that Bloom Energy sales "should benefit strongly" this year from a recent customer order of solid oxide fuel cells for a power generation plant in Wyoming.

Meanwhile, Evercore analysts wrote on Jan. 8 that the American Electric disclosure is a "meaningful positive" for Bloom Energy as it sheds light on the demand for its product. The firm has an outperform rating and a 152 price target on Bloom shares.

On Jan. 18, Morgan Stanley analysts also compiled a list of 18 "high conviction thematic stock ideas" across the U.S. and Latin America. Bloom Energy is one of the stocks.

Morgan Stanley sees Bloom Energy as playing a "pivotal role in the future of energy, particularly as an enabler of AI infrastructure and a solution to the emerging power bottleneck for data centers."

According to Morgan Stanley research, there could be a power shortfall of around 45 gigawatts for U.S. data centers through 2028. This is likely to lead to a substantial ramp in data center power demand with lengthy grid interconnection delays with some regions already experiencing five- to seven-year wait times, Morgan Stanley forecasts.

"As grid interconnection times lengthen and traditional power access becomes more constrained, Bloom's fuel cell technology represents a scarce resource in the market alongside U.S.-based solar panels and gas turbines, positioning it as a key beneficiary of the structural shift in how power is delivered to energy-intensive applications," Morgan Stanley analysts wrote.

Please follow Kit Norton on X @KitNorton for more coverage.

name: AXA
title: How Insurance Recapitalisation Is Unlocking Stronger Investment Returns
description:
Beyond regulatory compliance, this wave of recapitalisation is reshaping insurers’ balance sheets, expanding their investment capacity and opening new pathways for stronger, more sustainable investment returns for shareholders and institutional investors alike.
To expand insurance penetration: A more robust insurance sector can lead to increased insurance penetration, driving economic growth and creating new investment opportunities.
Looking at key insurance stocks to watch, capital market analysts have said that some insurance stocks that have rallied include: AIICO Insurance, Mutual Benefits Assurance, AXA Mansard Insurance, Linkage Assurance and Cornerstone Insurance.
The commissioner for Insurance/chief executive officer of NAICOM, Segun Omosehin, said the commission’s focus is to build a stronger, more credible insurance market that can protect policyholders and attract long-term investment.
Investing Smarter Via Insurance Recapitalisation To capitalize on this opportunity, investors should: * Monitor insurance stocks and their recapitalisation progress.
text:
Nigeria’s insurance sector is entering a new phase of capital strength following the introduction of the Nigerian Insurance Industry Reform Act (NIIRA) 2025, which mandates higher minimum capital requirements for operators. Beyond regulatory compliance, this wave of recapitalisation is reshaping insurers’ balance sheets, expanding their investment capacity and opening new pathways for stronger, more sustainable investment returns for shareholders and institutional investors alike.

The National Insurance Commission (NAICOM) has consequently set new minimum capital thresholds across the industry: N10 billion for life insurers, N15 billion for non-life insurers, N25 billion for composite insurers and N35 billion for reinsurers. The ongoing recapitalisation exercise is scheduled to conclude on July 30, 2026, giving operators a defined timeline to strengthen their capital base and reposition for growth.

As a result, several insurers have already approached shareholders for capital injections, while others are exploring strategic partnerships, rights issues, and potential mergers to meet the new regulatory thresholds and strengthen their market position.

The recapitalisation drive is expected to increase Investment Capacity with insurers with stronger balance sheets can invest in more substantial and diverse portfolios, potentially generating higher returns.

It will also improve governance and risk management: Enhanced capital requirements promote better governance and risk management practices, reducing the likelihood of insolvency and increasing investor confidence.

To expand insurance penetration: A more robust insurance sector can lead to increased insurance penetration, driving economic growth and creating new investment opportunities.

Looking at key insurance stocks to watch, capital market analysts have said that some insurance stocks that have rallied include: AIICO Insurance, Mutual Benefits Assurance, AXA Mansard Insurance, Linkage Assurance and Cornerstone Insurance.

The commissioner for Insurance/chief executive officer of NAICOM, Segun Omosehin, said the commission’s focus is to build a stronger, more credible insurance market that can protect policyholders and attract long-term investment.

“The recapitalisation and market conduct reforms are designed to ensure that insurance companies are financially sound, well governed and capable of meeting their obligations to policyholders. This will ultimately strengthen confidence in the industry,” Omosehin said.

A senior stockbroker, Tunde Oyediran emphasized that investors who truly understand the dynamics of the capital market must practice patience when it comes to their investments in companies, saying that “those who remain steadfast will likely see significant improvements in their investment portfolios over time.”

He encouraged a long-term perspective, stating, “the key is to stay committed to your company.”

Oyediran also highlighted the substantial untapped potential within the insurance sector, noting that “many Nigerians remain hesitant when it comes to embracing insurance products. This hesitation is a major concern, as effective legislation and enforcement could unlock the industry’s vast capabilities.”

He pointed out that a growing number of insurance firms are now diversifying their operations into various financial sectors, such as asset management and fintech, to solidify and enhance their income streams.

He stated that when the financial performance of these companies improves significantly, the benefits will inevitably extend to their investors in the form of better earnings and attractive dividends.

He mentioned several high-performing stocks in the market, including Custodian Investment Plc, NEM Insurance, Mansard Insurance, and Sunu Assurances, which are currently grabbing the attention of savvy investors seeking growth opportunities.

Investing Smarter Via Insurance Recapitalisation

To capitalize on this opportunity, investors should:

* Monitor insurance stocks and their recapitalisation progress.

* Consider investing in insurers with strong capital positions and growth potential.

* Diversify portfolios to include insurance sector investments.

Money Market

To finance the 2026 budget, the Chief Executive of CFG Advisory, Tilewa Adebajo, has urged the Federal Government to sell off part of its stake in its Joint Venture (JV) assets.

Speaking with journalists during the Finance Correspondents Association of Nigeria (FICAN) 2026 Economic Outlook, the economist warned that Nigeria’s current debt trajectory is unsustainable.

Adebajo who also projected that economic growth could exceed five per cent by the end of the year if urgent fiscal and structural reforms are implemented, said Nigeria’s debt profile, estimated at over $100 billion, poses a serious risk to macroeconomic stability.

Real Estate

The surging cost of house rents across Lagos, Ogun, Abuja, Port Harcourt, Asaba and other major Nigerian cities, amid largely stagnant incomes, is pushing many middle-class Nigerians into severe financial distress and, in some cases, homelessness.

Findings indicate that the cost of renting apartments and renewing leases in Lagos and its neighbouring Ogun communities has risen by more than 200 per cent in the past few years, deepening the housing burden on residents.

Market surveys show that rents for residential flats and small commercial spaces have jumped by over 90 per cent in several Lagos locations, including Lekki, Ajah, Surulere, Festac, Amuwo-Odofin, Apapa and Victoria Island.

Similarly, rents in suburban communities such as Ikotun, Ikorodu, Egbeda, Iyana-Ipaja, Agege, Abule-Egba and Ojodu-Berger have climbed sharply, moving beyond the affordability threshold of lower-income earners.

Maritime

Cargo haulage costs at the Tin Can Island and Apapa seaports in Lagos have dropped by 65.7 per cent, LEADERSHIP can report.

Findings show that the sharp decline is largely due to the introduction of the electronic call-up system, Ètò, operated by Truck Transit Park Limited (TTP), which has significantly improved truck movement and access to the ports.

Maritime experts attributed the reduction in haulage charges to shorter waiting times, faster truck turnaround, and the dismantling of racketeering and illegal checkpoints along port access roads.

text:
Advertisement

United States

/

Software

NasdaqGS:ADBE

Is Adobe (ADBE) Offering Value After A 31% One Year Share Price Decline

January 24, 2026

If you are wondering whether Adobe's current share price reflects its long term potential, it helps to separate the company’s story from what the market is currently willing to pay.

The stock last closed at US$301.07, with returns of 1.7% over 7 days, a 14.7% decline over 30 days, a 9.7% decline year to date, and a 30.8% decline over 1 year, which may have shifted how some investors see its growth prospects and risk profile.

These moves are playing out against a backdrop of ongoing interest in Adobe's core creative and digital media platforms, as investors weigh the long term value of its subscription based model and product ecosystem. Recent coverage has also focused on broader sentiment toward large software names, which can influence how quickly investors are willing to pay up for growth and established market positions.

On our checks Adobe currently scores 5 out of 6 on valuation, as shown by its . Next we will compare the different ways to look at that valuation, before finishing with a different framework that can help you judge whether the market price truly matches your own view of the company.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Adobe Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model projects a company’s future cash flows and then discounts them back to today’s value, so you can compare that estimate to the current share price.

For Adobe, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach based on cash flow projections. The latest twelve month free cash flow is about $9.8b, and analysts have provided explicit forecasts out to 2030, with Simply Wall St extrapolating further to build a 10 year view. For example, the projections show free cash flow in 2030 of $13.0b, with interim annual estimates such as $10.3b in 2026 and $11.2b in 2027, all in $ and then discounted back to today.

Bringing all those discounted cash flows together, the DCF model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of about $532.26 per share. Against the recent share price of $301.07, this implies the stock is around 43.4% undervalued according to this framework.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Adobe is undervalued by 43.4%. Track this in your or , or discover .

Approach 2: Adobe Price vs Earnings

For profitable companies like Adobe, the P/E ratio is a useful way to relate what you pay per share to the earnings the business is currently generating. It gives you a quick sense of how many dollars investors are paying for each dollar of earnings.

What counts as a “normal” P/E depends on factors such as expected earnings growth and perceived risk. Higher growth and lower risk often support a higher multiple, while slower growth or higher uncertainty usually call for a lower one.

Adobe currently trades on a P/E of 17.33x. That sits below the Software industry average of 30.76x and well below a peer group average of 55.29x. Simply Wall St’s Fair Ratio framework estimates a P/E of 34.31x for Adobe, based on variables like its earnings profile, industry, profit margins, market value and risk characteristics.

This Fair Ratio aims to be more tailored than a simple comparison with peers or the broad industry, because it adjusts for company specific factors instead of assuming all software names deserve the same multiple. Compared with the current P/E of 17.33x, the Fair Ratio of 34.31x suggests the shares trade below that model’s implied level.

Result: UNDERVALUED

P/E ratios tell one story, but what if the real opportunity lies elsewhere? .

Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose Your Adobe Narrative

Earlier we mentioned that there is an even better way to understand valuation, so let us introduce you to Narratives, a simple way to connect your view of Adobe’s story with the numbers behind its fair value.

A Narrative is your explanation of what you think will happen to a company, written as a story that is backed by your own assumptions for future revenue, earnings and margins, which then link directly into an estimated fair value per share.

On Simply Wall St, millions of investors use Narratives on the Community page as an easy tool to translate their views into financial forecasts, compare the resulting fair value to the current share price and decide whether that gap is significant enough for them to consider buying or selling.

Because Narratives on the platform update when new information such as news or earnings is added, your fair value view can adjust automatically. You might see one Adobe Narrative that assumes a relatively high fair value based on optimistic growth and margins, while another assumes a far lower fair value based on more cautious expectations, even though both are using the same underlying framework.

Do you think there's more to the story for Adobe?

We provide commentary based on historical data and analyst forecasts only using an unbiased methodology and our articles are not intended to be financial advice. It does not constitute a recommendation to buy or sell any stock, and does not take account of your objectives, or your financial situation. We aim to bring you long-term focused analysis driven by fundamental data. Note that our analysis may not factor in the latest price-sensitive company announcements or qualitative material. text:
Leidos Holdings (NYSE:LDOS) has announced a new partnership with OpenAI to bring advanced artificial intelligence tools into federal agency operations.

The collaboration targets productivity gains, faster product development, and stronger national security capabilities across government programs.

The initiative focuses on applying generative AI to areas such as defense, infrastructure, and health services for federal clients.

For investors tracking NYSE:LDOS, this AI partnership arrives as the stock trades around $193.45, with a 1 year return of 31.2% and a 3 year return of 105.2%. Those figures place Leidos in a group of defense and government IT contractors that have seen renewed attention around digital modernization and mission critical technology.

The OpenAI collaboration indicates that AI may be a central theme in how Leidos positions itself with federal agencies going forward. If you follow the stock, this development may be worth watching for how it influences contract discussions, competitive positioning, and the types of solutions Leidos brings to government clients over time.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for Leidos Holdings by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on Leidos Holdings.

This OpenAI partnership ties directly into Leidos' focus areas in digital modernization, health services, national security, infrastructure, and defense, which are described as foundations of its NorthStar 2030 growth strategy. For you as an investor, the key angle is how deeply OpenAI's generative and agentic AI is embedded into core federal workflows, since that can influence Leidos' ability to compete for larger and more complex contracts tied to long term modernization programs.

Leidos Holdings Narrative, Now With an AI Twist

There is no formal narrative data attached here, but this announcement may feed into existing investor storylines that already link Leidos to government IT spending, cybersecurity, and digital modernization. If you view Leidos as a contractor closely aligned with U.S. federal priorities, the closer integration of OpenAI tools into both customer workflows and internal processes could reinforce that story around execution on long range technology programs.

Risks and rewards investors should keep in mind

The company is flagged with 4 rewards, including comments that it is trading at 33.4% below one fair value estimate and that earnings grew 16.9% over the past year.

Earnings are also described as forecast to grow 3.77% per year, while the stock is noted as trading at good value compared to peers and the industry.

There is 1 identified risk linked to a high level of debt, which could matter if AI investments or contract delivery require significant ongoing spending.

Management highlights internal productivity gains from thousands of employees already using OpenAI's platform daily, which could support margins if executed carefully.

What to watch next

From here, it is worth watching how often Leidos references OpenAI powered solutions in contract wins, backlog disclosures, and product announcements, as well as any commentary on operational efficiencies from AI use across its workforce. title: Euro zone business activity expands steadily but price pressures reemerge - WTAQ
description:
By Indradip Ghosh BENGALURU, Jan 23 (Reuters) – Euro zone business activity growth held steady this month as a weaker expansion in the dominant services industry offset milder factory contraction, according to a survey, while price pressures picked up.
It remained ‌above the 50.0 level that separates growth from contraction for a ‌13th straight month.
“Overall, these are decent data, supporting the view of a relatively resilient euro zone economy in the face of multiple shocks and ongoing policy uncertainty,” said Claus Vistesen, chief euro zone economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics.
In Germany, business activity grew at its fastest pace in three months in January but employment fell at the quickest rate ‍since November 2009.
However, activity in France unexpectedly contracted in January, after two months of meagre growth.
text:
By Indradip Ghosh

BENGALURU, Jan 23 (Reuters) – Euro zone business activity growth held steady this month as a weaker expansion in the dominant services industry offset milder factory contraction, according to a survey, while price pressures picked up.

The common ‍currency bloc started the year on a weaker note but sentiment has improved since Wednesday after U.S. President Donald Trump backed down on additional tariffs he had threatened to impose on eight European countries as leverage to seize Greenland.

The HCOB Flash Eurozone Composite PMI, compiled by S&P Global, held at 51.5 this month but fell short of a Reuters poll forecast for 51.8. It remained ‌above the 50.0 level that separates growth from contraction for a ‌13th straight month.

“Overall, these are decent data, supporting the view of a relatively resilient euro zone economy in the face of multiple shocks and ongoing policy uncertainty,” said Claus Vistesen, chief euro zone economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics. “That said, the bar to meet official and consensus forecasts is ​now higher.”

PRICE PRESSURES BACK ON RADAR

New orders rose at the weakest rate since September and new export business contracted at the quickest pace in four months, suggesting demand remained ‍weak across the board. Firms shed jobs for ​the first time since September.

The services PMI slowed to a four-month ​low of 51.9 from 52.4 in December, lower than the Reuters poll prediction of 52.6.

Manufacturing activity ‍contracted again but at a slower pace.

An index measuring output, which feeds into the composite PMI, barely returned to expansion territory but new orders contracted for a third straight month.

PMIs showed mixed activity across the bloc. In Germany, business activity grew at its fastest pace in three months in January but employment fell at the quickest rate ‍since November 2009.

However, activity in France unexpectedly contracted in January, after two months of meagre growth.

In Britain, a separate PMI showed businesses reported the fastest growth since April 2024. But inflation ‍and joblessness increased, too.

Overall price ‍pressures intensified with input costs rising at the fastest rate ​since February and output charges increasing at the quickest pace in ​nearly two ⁠years, reinforcing expectations the European Central Bank will keep rates ‌steady.

“Even though inflation has remained remarkably benign in recent months despite all the economic turmoil, the PMI does indicate increasing price pressures again,” said Bert Colijn at ING. “That being said, the moves are not nearly enough to sway the ECB from its expectations to hold rates for the foreseeable future.”

Still, optimism about future activity rose to its highest since May 2024.

(Reporting by Indradip Ghosh; ⁠Editing by Toby Chopra)

About Boston Scientific

(Free Report)

name: Societe Generale
title: Ménage à la SAAQ: le nouveau PDG, Serge Lamontagne, «ne peut pas attendre l'UPAC
description:
Malgré l’ombre de l’UPAC qui plane au-dessus de son organisation, le nouveau PDG de la SAAQ, Serge Lamontagne, compte faire rapidement le ménage exigé par le gouvernement.
Le quatrième président-directeur général (PDG) en trois ans à la Société de l'assurance automobile du Québec (SAAQ) l’a déjà vécu comme directeur général à la Ville de Laval.
Le nouveau PDG ne compte pas attendre les conclusions du corps de police pour poser des gestes importants.
«Les mots clés pour moi: gouvernance, transparence et reddition de comptes», a mentionné le PDG, qui se veut rassurant.
Puis, le nouveau PDG tranchera rapidement la question de la sécurité et de l’armement des contrôleurs routiers.
text:
Malgré l’ombre de l’UPAC qui plane au-dessus de son organisation, le nouveau PDG de la SAAQ, Serge Lamontagne, compte faire rapidement le ménage exigé par le gouvernement.

Le mandat ne sera pas facile, admet Serge Lamontagne.

Le quatrième président-directeur général (PDG) en trois ans à la Société de l'assurance automobile du Québec (SAAQ) l’a déjà vécu comme directeur général à la Ville de Laval. L’administration y était gangrenée par la corruption de l’ex-maire Gilles Vaillancourt.

Il devait y faire le ménage, mais il se veut toutefois rassurant: il n’agira pas comme un rouleau compresseur.

«Quand on arrive dans un contexte de tutelle et de corruption, les gens pensent qu’on va faire le ménage. [À Laval], oui, il y a des gens qui sont partis parce que la réorganisation était difficile. Il y en a à qui j’ai demandé de quitter. Mais la transformation s’est faite avec la majorité des gens», a-t-il expliqué, en entrevue avec notre Bureau parlementaire.

Le PDG prendra d’ailleurs le pouls des 5000 employés cette année, conscient que plusieurs sont échaudés par les trois dernières années et la mauvaise presse qui a déferlé à leur endroit.

L’UPAC en tête

Comme pour la SAAQ, Laval faisait l’objet d’enquêtes de l’unité permanente anticorruption (UPAC) à son entrée en fonction. Le nouveau PDG ne compte pas attendre les conclusions du corps de police pour poser des gestes importants.

«À Laval, j’ai travaillé en parallèle avec l’UPAC. Les enquêtes sont longues. Au niveau administratif, je ne peux pas attendre. Il faut avancer sans nuire aux enquêtes. S’il y a des accusations, on prendra acte et on agira en conséquence», dit-il.

«Quand on a un mandat comme ça, il faut scruter le passé, planifier et protéger l’avenir. Ici, le passé a déjà été largement scruté avec la Vérificatrice générale (VG), l’Autorité des marchés publics (AMP), la commission Galant», rappelle-t-il.

D’ailleurs, en écoutant cette commission, M. Lamontagne dit être «tombé en bas de [sa] chaise».

«J’ai été renversé par l’envergure du dossier», signale-t-il, admettant avoir été scandalisé.

Grosses responsabilités

Le nouveau PDG identifie d’ailleurs quatre priorités. D’abord, intégrer l’ensemble des rapports d’enquête afin d’élaborer un plan d’action global et empêcher la répétition des erreurs. Le rapport dévastateur de l’AMP le forcera à montrer patte blanche tous les six mois.

Un concept qu’il apprécie, assure-t-il.

«Les mots clés pour moi: gouvernance, transparence et reddition de comptes», a mentionné le PDG, qui se veut rassurant.

M. Lamontagne souhaite aussi s’attaquer au déficit budgétaire de l’organisation, qui pourrait frôler le milliard de dollars d’ici 2029 en raison de SAAQclic.

Fort de son expérience de gestion, il est convaincu d’y arriver. «On doit retrouver l’équilibre», signale-t-il.

La troisième priorité vise l’amélioration des services aux citoyens et l’optimisation des processus, malgré un système informatique incomplet.

Puis, le nouveau PDG tranchera rapidement la question de la sécurité et de l’armement des contrôleurs routiers. Le ministre des Transports, Jonatan Julien, lui en a donné rapidement la mission.

Serge Lamontagne

name: Uber
outlet: Institute of Science and Technology Austria (ISTA)
title: ISTA Receives €5 Million Donation for AI Research
description:
“It helps us pursue AI research within a broad, interdisciplinary scientific context, deepen our understanding of how these systems work, and address their limitations.
“Camp’s donation acknowledges the excellence of the Austrian research landscape.” ISTA as AI hub ISTA’s work in AI is wide-ranging and focuses on building systems that are reliable, efficient and scientifically grounded.
Sustainable AI is another ISTA focus, with research led by Dan Alistarh aimed at making AI models more resource-efficient and broadly accessible.
At ISTA, AI is also closely integrated with other research fields.
Bolstered by the donation, these and other ISTA researchers ­including Krishnendu Chatterjee, Thomas Henzinger, and Matthew Robinson will continue to contribute to AI research that is both scientifically robust and socially responsible.
text:
The Institute of Science and Technology Austria (ISTA) has received a donation of 5 million euros from Canadian philanthropist and entrepreneur Garrett Camp to help advance AI as a trustworthy, human-centered technology that benefits society. ISTA’s commitment to responsible AI, coupled with its focus on frontier research and interdisciplinary culture, make it perfectly placed to pursue this goal.

Camp – a philanthropist who is the creator of the not-for-profit Camp.org research organization and co-founder of the ride-hailing Uber app – visited the ISTA campus on January 13 to sign the donation agreement with President Martin Hetzer and Managing Director Georg Schneider.

“With this generous gift, ISTA can further build upon fundamental research in artificial intelligence, drawing on our strengths in computer science, mathematics, and the natural sciences,” said Hetzer. “It helps us pursue AI research within a broad, interdisciplinary scientific context, deepen our understanding of how these systems work, and address their limitations. It is essential for developing robust and trustworthy AI systems that deliver long-term value for both science and society.”

Investment in future breakthroughs

For Camp, the ISTA donation reflects a belief that the next generation of AI breakthroughs will come from ecosystems that prioritize rigor, collaboration, and long-term impact over short-term speed. His current focus is centered around facilitating AI development that helps people thrive around the world.

“Global solutions demand global perspectives and collaboration,” said Camp. “Supporting ISTA is about investing in a community that unites brilliant minds from around the world to further advance trustworthy AI in harmony with humanity and helps to ensure that innovation continues to grow with integrity, transparency, and respect for human values.” Camp has a history of supporting non-profit organizations focused on building responsible and trustworthy AI technology. However, the ISTA gift represents his first contribution to a European research institution.

“We are thrilled to have played a role in helping bring these two institutions together,” said Niklas Schmidt of Wolf Theiss Attorneys-at-Law. “Camp’s donation acknowledges the excellence of the Austrian research landscape.”

ISTA as AI hub

ISTA’s work in AI is wide-ranging and focuses on building systems that are reliable, efficient and scientifically grounded. Key areas include trustworthy AI, with researchers such as Christoph Lampert and his team striving for principled solutions rather than just bug fixes while seeking to make AI safer, as well as more robust, fair and respectful of data privacy.

Sustainable AI is another ISTA focus, with research led by Dan Alistarh aimed at making AI models more resource-efficient and broadly accessible. Francesco Locatello and his team work on causal AI aimed at helping AI systems learn how causes lead to effects, how actions change outcomes and how data they encounter can shift over time.

At ISTA, AI is also closely integrated with other research fields. That includes experimentally aware AI for protein structure prediction. In this area, Alex Bronstein, in collaboration with Paul Schanda, developed a method to ‘guide’ the AlphaFold3 AI model to match experimental data. Monika Henzinger meanwhile pursues work on the privacy-preserving training of large language models while Marco Mondelli and his group have developed rigorous methods for exploiting massive datasets and solving complex inference problems.

Bolstered by the donation, these and other ISTA researchers ­including Krishnendu Chatterjee, Thomas Henzinger, and Matthew Robinson will continue to contribute to AI research that is both scientifically robust and socially responsible.

“We greatly value this transatlantic vote of confidence in ISTA’s research mission and in our role in shaping the future of AI,” Hetzer said. Since opening its doors in 2009, ISTA has attracted scientists from around the world who carry out foundational research spanning the natural sciences, mathematics and computer science across roughly 90 groups, with that number expected to increase to 150 over the next decade.

name: Societe Generale
title: Anas Laghrari, Florentino Pérez's banker shaping Real Madrid's new era - OneFootball
description:
Anas Laghrari has emerged as Florentino Pérez’s trusted banker at Real Madrid and ACS.
Born in 1984, he studied financial mathematics in France, joined Calyon, then moved to Madrid with Société Générale in 2009.
His father partnered with Pérez in Moroccan construction projects.
He helped steady ACS after the failed Iberdrola bid and the property crisis, as the March family and the ‘Albertos’ distanced themselves from Pérez.
He has been involved in Madrid’s Providence and Sixth Street agreements, and in ACS’s purchase of Abertis.
text:
Anas Laghrari has emerged as Florentino Pérez’s trusted banker at Real Madrid and ACS. According to El Periódico Mediterráneo, the Moroccan financier now sits inside the president’s inner circle.

Born in 1984, he studied financial mathematics in France, joined Calyon, then moved to Madrid with Société Générale in 2009. Headed locally by friend Donato González, the bank was Pérez’s main lender before his presidency. His father partnered with Pérez in Moroccan construction projects.

Laghrari left Société Générale in 2013 to become a partner at Key Capital. He helped steady ACS after the failed Iberdrola bid and the property crisis, as the March family and the ‘Albertos’ distanced themselves from Pérez.

He has been involved in Madrid’s Providence and Sixth Street agreements, and in ACS’s purchase of Abertis. A co-founder of A22 Sports Managment, linked to Key Capital, he shaped the Super League’s financing, securing €4,000 million from JP Morgan and negotiating with signatory clubs. He also advised Joan Laporta and Barcelona.

The club has floated a new CEO to run a subsidiary for business operations, separate from the presidency and sporting side, handling investors, Bernabéu commercial activity and a model valued by Pérez at €10,000 million. Laghrari fits that brief and is bringing Sixth Street and Bernard Arnault to buy the 5% on offer. Some members view him as a risk and even a possible successor, while a revised ethics code has enabled deputy managing director Carlos Ocaña, a Telefónica vice-president representing the Sociedad Estatal de Participaciones Industriales, to join.

name: OpenAI
title: OpenAI hustling for Gulf dollars. Subsidizing the ranchers. Schumpeter on democracy.
description:
La tutela del patrimonio architettonico Source: area-arch OpenAI hustling for Gulf dollars.
As President Donald Trump’s administration pushes a pro-ranching agenda, ProPublica and High Country News investigated how public lands ranching has evolved.
We also found that, in 2024 alone, the federal government poured at least $2.5 billion into subsidy programs that public lands ranchers can access.
A small number of wealthy individuals and corporations manage most livestock on public lands.
And on Forest Service land, the top 10% of permittees control more than 50% of grazing.
text:
Thank you for opening your Chartbook email.

L’architettura del ‘900. La tutela del patrimonio architettonico

Source: area-arch

OpenAI hustling for Gulf dollars.

Source: Bloomberg

Dario Perkins on the central bank-economics-FT loop

Source: TSLombard “How to be a central banker” 30 October 2024 Dario Perkins

How American government subsidizes its ranchers

The federal government allows livestock grazing across an area of publicly owned land more than twice the size of California, making ranching the largest land use in the West. Billions of dollars of taxpayer subsidies support the system, which often harms the environment.

As President Donald Trump’s administration pushes a pro-ranching agenda, ProPublica and High Country News investigated how public lands ranching has evolved. We filed more than 100 public record requests and sued the Bureau of Land Management to pry free documents and data; we interviewed everyone from ranchers to conservationists; and we toured ranching operations in Arizona, Colorado, Montana and Nevada. The resulting three-part investigation digs into the subsidies baked into ranching, the environmental impacts from livestock and the political clout that protects this status quo. Here are the takeaways from that work. The public lands grazing system was modernized in the 1930s in response to the rampant use of natural resources that led to the Dust Bowl — the massive dust storms triggered by poor agricultural practices, including overgrazing. Today, the system focuses on subsidizing the continued grazing of these lands.

The BLM and Forest Service, the two largest federal land management agencies, oversee most of the system. Combined, the agencies charged ranchers $21 million in grazing fees in 2024. Our analysis found that to be about a 93% discount, on average, compared with the market rate for forage on private land. We also found that, in 2024 alone, the federal government poured at least $2.5 billion into subsidy programs that public lands ranchers can access. Such subsidies include disaster assistance after droughts and floods as well as compensation for livestock lost to predators. A small number of wealthy individuals and corporations manage most livestock on public lands.

Roughly two-thirds of the grazing on BLM acreage is controlled by just 10% of ranchers, our analysis found. And on Forest Service land, the top 10% of permittees control more than 50% of grazing. Among the largest ranchers are billionaires like Stan Kroenke and Rupert Murdoch, as well as mining companies and public utilities. The administration released a “plan to fortify the American Beef Industry” in October that instructed the BLM and Forest Service to amend grazing regulations for the first time since the 1990s.

The plan suggested that taxpayers further support ranching by increasing subsidies for drought and wildfire relief, livestock killed by predators and government-backed insurance. The White House referred questions to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, which said in a statement, “Livestock grazing is not only a federally and statutorily recognized appropriate land use, but a proven land management tool, one that reduces invasive species and wildfire risk, enhances ecosystem health, and supports rural stewardship.” Roughly 18,000 permittees graze livestock on BLM or Forest Service land, most of them small operations. These ranchers say they need government support and cheaper grazing fees to avoid insolvency.

Source: ProPublica

Source: Il Giornale dell’architettura

The most amazing city.

The final paragraph of Joseph Schumpeter’s chapter-length introduction of his theory of democracy is such a banger

Source: J.A. Schumpter, Capitalism, Socialsm and Democracy. 1943.

For interesting commentary see “Democracy Before, In, and After Schumpeter” Philip Pettit

The classical model of democracy that Schumpeter criticizes is manufactured out of a variety of earlier ideas, not those of any one thinker or even one school of thought. His critique of the central ideals by which he defines the model—those of the common will and the common good—remains persuasive. People’s preferences are too messy and too manipulable to allow us to think that mass democracy can promote those ideals, as he defines them. Should we endorse his purely electoral model of democracy, then, and accept that people do not exercise any control over government? Not necessarily. We can expand democracy to include the constitutional and contestatory constraints that people impose on their rulers. We may hope that people can rely on such democratic controls to ensure that government operates by community standards.

Source: Taylor and Francis

name: IBM
outlet: IBM Shares: A Test of Resilience Ahead of Earnings
title: IBM Shares: A Test of Resilience Ahead of Earnings - AD HOC NEWS
description:
As International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) approaches a pivotal quarterly report, a notable divergence has emerged between its recent stock performance and analyst sentiment.
Market experts, on average, anticipate earnings per share of $4.31, which would represent a year-over-year increase.
Grammy Alliance: For the 2026 awards ceremony, IBM will provide a digital AI experience, showcasing its technology to a vast global audience.
Analyst Consensus Defies Recent Price Action The recent share price correction has not dampened the view from several major investment houses.
The coming earnings presentation is seen as a potential catalyst to reconcile the disconnect between the stock's recent weakness and the upbeat analyst commentary.
text:
As International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) approaches a pivotal quarterly report, a notable divergence has emerged between its recent stock performance and analyst sentiment. Despite a significant weekly decline that saw shares lose approximately 15% of their value, closing at €259.25 last Friday, a wave of optimism persists among Wall Street observers. The upcoming financial release on Wednesday, January 28, after the U.S. market close, is now viewed as a critical juncture that could determine whether the technology giant can leverage its strategic initiatives to stabilize its equity value.

All eyes are on the fourth-quarter results, where forecasts are ambitious. Market experts, on average, anticipate earnings per share of $4.31, which would represent a year-over-year increase. Revenue growth is also projected to be robust, with estimates pointing to an advance of nearly 10%. Analysts will scrutinize several key areas: the performance of the software division, recognized as a primary engine for margin expansion; commentary on the planned acquisition of Confluent; and the trajectory of cash flow, which directly impacts the company's dividend sustainability. The report and subsequent guidance for 2026 are expected to set the market's tone for the coming months.

Strategic Moves in AI Fuel Confidence

A primary source of the prevailing positive outlook is IBM's aggressive expansion within the artificial intelligence sector. The company has launched multiple initiatives this week designed to solidify its market position:

Should investors sell immediately? Or is it worth buying IBM?

Enterprise Consulting: A new advisory service aimed at helping businesses scale their AI applications built on the watsonx platform.

Grammy Alliance: For the 2026 awards ceremony, IBM will provide a digital AI experience, showcasing its technology to a vast global audience.

Telecom Partnership: In collaboration with telecommunications firm e&, a new solution for governance and compliance has been developed, targeting a high-margin segment of the software market.

Analyst Consensus Defies Recent Price Action

The recent share price correction has not dampened the view from several major investment houses. In January, firms including Jefferies and Bank of America raised their price targets for IBM. Notably, Jefferies upgraded its rating on the stock from "Hold" to "Buy." The overall consensus among researchers now leans toward a "Moderate Buy" recommendation. Out of 19 analysts covering the company, 13 currently advise purchasing the shares.

Market strategists interpret this sustained confidence as an indication that the recent decline is more attributable to a pre-earnings market adjustment rather than a reflection of deteriorating fundamentals. The coming earnings presentation is seen as a potential catalyst to reconcile the disconnect between the stock's recent weakness and the upbeat analyst commentary. Should IBM confirm strong growth in its AI-driven segments and provide a reassuring outlook, it may well validate the current optimism and chart a new course for its shares.

name: New York Public Library
title: AIDS took Ross Laycock 35 years ago. His legacy lives on - Yahoo
description:
I’m remembering Ross today, who died of AIDS-related illnesses, 35 years ago on January 24, 1991.
I met Ross in 1978 while we were students at McGill University — he a science major, and me, art history.
The first time I saw Ross and Felix together was at a cocktail party in Manhattan in 1983.
It was obvious that Ross had finally found in Felix his ideal man, and Felix had found his “audience of one."
This article originally appeared on Out: AIDS took Ross Laycock 35 years ago.
text:
Memory is a tricky thing.

My friend Felix Gonzalez-Torres once said, "Each of us perceives things according to who and how we are at particular junctures, whose terms are always shifting."

So I think, OK, I've had a great life with memories culled from a long list of fantastic, seemingly improbable, some say phantasmagorical experiences and friendships. But for me, it's as though these things happened to someone else, and I only realized how important they were after the fact. I'm not sure if it was naïveté, or my terminally blasé nature, or my Teflon indifference, as one exasperated therapist called it.

One of the few memories that has always felt very real to me dates to my childhood in Canada, when, on cold winter days, with snow drifts like white, ominous mountains enveloping that place I called home, I’d rush from school, lace up my skates, and trudge across the snow drifts, down to the river's edge. Alone, I would skate for miles in the early evening silence, just the schoosh schoosh of the blades on the rock hard ice, the witchy blackness of the early night, and my plumed breath in regular procession.

It is this memory that conjures up Ross Laycock, my indomitable gay brother, the prankster, the exuberant athlete and opera buff, the very embodiment of a certain kind of Canadian sprezzatura. Ross, who like so many, was murdered by Ronald Reagan’s toxic black hair dye and Nancy Reagan’s blood-stained Adolfo dress. By Jesse Helms’s southern-fried homophobia, and New York Mayor Ed Koch’s slammed-shut and padlocked closet door. I’m remembering Ross today, who died of AIDS-related illnesses, 35 years ago on January 24, 1991.

I met Ross in 1978 while we were students at McGill University — he a science major, and me, art history. Then, in the spring of 1980, Ross moved to New York to study menswear design at the Fashion Institute of Technology but soon realized he was not a fit for FIT — that he’d rather buy clothes than design them. I arrived six months later in November. As different as two young gay men could be, I felt deeply bonded to Ross because he represented a kind of unfettered freedom I had never known or understood, and for him, I was the brother he never had.

The first time I saw Ross and Felix together was at a cocktail party in Manhattan in 1983. The two had met a few weeks prior and were already madly in love. It was obvious that Ross had finally found in Felix his ideal man, and Felix had found his “audience of one." I gave my approval.

Their intense relationship played itself out within the context of Reagan’s America, a time of great difficulty for many people, in particular gay men and lesbians. For some of us, it was also a time of great creativity and profound personal change, of art-making and vibrant activism centered on a spiraling “government-sponsored holocaust” as art critic Darren Jones named it. We opened our hearts and minds and grew in ways we never knew possible, but the tsunami of AIDS came roaring in and threatened to drown us.

Ross came from a family of girls — three sisters, where they all grew up in Inuvik, the Northwest Territories of Canada, in a small village called Norman Wells. I believe there is a kind of spectacular and unique beauty to that place, as he described it, but also boredom and tedium for a young boy. His father died when he was nine, and I know that affected him deeply. His mother, with few options, sent him to what is known in Canada as a "residential school," an awful place, funded by the Canadian government, which forced Indigenous children to not speak their native languages, give up rituals and traditions including clothing, food, hunting, and adornments, and be indoctrinated into the Catholic liturgy. They used torture, starvation, psychological manipulation, and even murder to bend these children to the white man’s way. “Ross, as the only non-Indigenous student at the school, was bullied and abused by other students. I think his confidence, resilience, and charm helped him survive,” his sister Janice remembered. That is the adult Ross that I knew, and the Ross that Felix fell in love with, who he described as “strong as a horse; he could build anything.”

They were in so many ways the most unlikely/likely pair. Felix had been born and raised in Guaimaro, Cuba — the birthplace of the Cuban independence movement, and was separated from his parents in their decision to get him and his siblings out of Cuba as Castro swept into power. This left him feeling unmoored and alone until he eventually landed in New York City where he found a sense of home, something most important to both of them, and which they found in each other.

Ross eventually left New York and returned to Canada to continue his studies in biochemistry at the University of Toronto. He and Felix continued their love affair traveling between New York and Toronto, to Paris, Italy, and spending months in Los Angeles while Felix taught a semester at CalArts. They would spend every summer traveling the northland of Ontario, sleeping in a VW minivan, cooking over an open fire, hiking, swimming, and watching beavers build their dams, while Harry, Ross’s black Labrador, chased squirrels.

Ross became involved with the activist group AIDS Action Now!, and in 1989, organized direct actions at the fifth International AIDS Conference in Montreal, cowriting a manifesto of demands activists issued to the government of Canada as they stormed the stage at the opening plenary session.

I think of Dr. Martin Luther King’s famous phrase: "The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends toward justice." And it gives me hope. I appreciate the hard-won gains we in the LBGTQ+ community have made in the last 40 years, which were built upon the foundations laid by our brothers and sisters in the 60 years prior. And young people, who are smart and savvy, and seem to have a broad sense of acceptance and love for each other, without judgment, is the very definition of progress. Still, there is more to do.

Thing is, the arc of justice sometimes snaps back, and we find ourselves, once again, facing ugly prejudice, extreme threats of violence, and seemingly impossible odds. Now, hateful anti-trans legislation is being passed in many states, and misogynistic rhetoric spews daily from the Oval Office. We see the current administration canceling World AIDS Day and threatening the highly effective PEPFAR global health initiative, which provided life-saving care to people in developing nations around the world.

We also see pernicious attempts to erase our very existence, and our love, like at recent exhibitions of Felix’s work at the David Zwirner Gallery in New York, the Chicago Art Institute, and the Smithsonian National Portrait Gallery, where Ross’s name was very intentionally either marginalized, or completely erased from gallery and museum labels and catalogues, along with words like gay, Latino, Cuban, HIV, and AIDS in biographical information about Felix — who was, in fact, all of those things and more.

I know a few things from my years as an artist and activist. Organizing and direct action works, community building works and nonviolent protest works. But mostly I know, even with these setbacks, we will survive.

A 1984 portrait of Carl George by Felix Gonzalez-TorresFelix Gonzalez-Torres / Courtesy Carl George

The last time I saw my friends Ross and Felix together was as a huge pile of candy on a museum floor in New York City. The installation, Untitled (“Lover Boys”) 1991, had an ideal weight of 355 pounds of thousands of shimmering, silver, foil-wrapped candies, and was equal to the weight of the two men combined. Visitors to this installation, which Felix created for the Whitney Museum's 1991 Biennial Exhibition, were invited to take pieces of the candy, and as they did, the pile slowly dwindled — a metaphor for the gradual dissipation of two lives. It forged a charged connection between public dissemination and private ownership, popular discourse and rarified art theory, between the daily lives of gay Americans and the right-wing maelstrom sweeping the nation in the epidemic's early years.

I remember that glorious summer day on Jones Beach when I took the photo of Felix and Ross, bursting with love for each other, looking sexy and glamorous, not a care in the world. But it was not to be. Just a few years later, I gave Ross his last bath, his skeletal body covered with Kaposi’s sarcoma lesions. And soon thereafter, my friend Sharron Campeau and I made funeral arrangements to his exacting specifications; that his ashes be separated into 100 small bags so Felix could carry him everywhere and leave a bit of Ross in the places they both loved.

Carl George is an experimental filmmaker and curator who has presented screenings and exhibitions in art venues and museums internationally. His films are in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art, the Whitney, the Guggenheim, and the New York Public Library. George is the recipient of many grants and honors, including the Canada Council for the Arts, the New York State Council for the Arts, and the Getty Research Institute where his archive of personal correspondence resides.

Learn more at carlmgeorge.com. Find him on Instagram @carlmgeorge.

Opinion is dedicated to featuring a wide range of inspiring personal stories and impactful opinions from the LGBTQ+ community and its allies. Visit Out.com/submit to learn more about submission guidelines. We welcome your thoughts and feedback on any of our stories. Email us at voices@equalpride.com. Views expressed in Opinion stories are those of the guest writers, columnists, and editors, and do not directly represent the views of Out or our parent company, equalpride.

This article originally appeared on Out: AIDS took Ross Laycock 35 years ago. His legacy lives on

name: Nvidia
title: Nvidia CEO tours Shanghai amid fresh signs of China thaw
description:
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang has begun his latest trip to China – visiting a grocery market in Shanghai on Saturday after touring the chipmaker’s local office – at a time when Beijing is expected to allow imports of the company’s H200 artificial intelligence chips.
Huang was seen at a grocery market on Saturday in Shanghai’s busy Lujiazui area, looking relaxed, according to multiple photos circulated on social media.
He is expected to arrive in Beijing on Monday, with the office’s annual Lunar New Year celebration taking place that evening, according to an Nvidia employee.
Besides Beijing, Huang is also expected to visit Nvidia staff in Shenzhen, continuing a routine he has followed over the past two years to mark the Lunar New Year with employees and business partners.
The visit comes at a critical moment for Nvidia, as the H200 – its second most powerful AI chip – has yet to clear regulatory hurdles in China.
text:
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang has begun his latest trip to China – visiting a grocery market in Shanghai on Saturday after touring the chipmaker’s local office – at a time when Beijing is expected to allow imports of the company’s H200 artificial intelligence chips.

Huang was seen at a grocery market on Saturday in Shanghai’s busy Lujiazui area, looking relaxed, according to multiple photos circulated on social media.

Earlier, Huang met with Shanghai-based staff to review Nvidia’s milestones for 2025 and to discuss its product pipeline for the year ahead, although the H200 was not mentioned in the discussion, Tencent Holdings’ news portal reported on Friday.

He is expected to arrive in Beijing on Monday, with the office’s annual Lunar New Year celebration taking place that evening, according to an Nvidia employee.

Besides Beijing, Huang is also expected to visit Nvidia staff in Shenzhen, continuing a routine he has followed over the past two years to mark the Lunar New Year with employees and business partners. This year’s holiday begins in mid-February.

Nvidia did not immediately respond to an email inquiry sent on Saturday.

The visit comes at a critical moment for Nvidia, as the H200 – its second most powerful AI chip – has yet to clear regulatory hurdles in China. Last week, Washington approved exports of the chip, with the US government set to collect a 25 per cent fee. However, Beijing’s temporary import ban has cast uncertainty over its availability.

name: OpenAI
title: OpenAI Accelerates Global and Enterprise Strategy With India Engagement and Leadership Shift
description:
OpenAI is intensifying its global expansion and enterprise focus as chief executive Sam Altman prepares for a planned visit to India in mid-February, coinciding with the India AI Impact Summit 2026 in New Delhi.
While Altman is not listed as a formal speaker, OpenAI is expected to host closed-door meetings and a private industry event during summit week, engaging investors, enterprise customers, and policymakers.
Separately, OpenAI has reorganized its leadership to strengthen enterprise sales, appointing Barret Zoph to lead global efforts to sell AI to business customers.
Zoph, a former OpenAI vice president who recently returned after a stint at Thinking Machine Labs, takes on the role as enterprise AI adoption becomes a central priority for 2026.
OpenAI has also expanded partnerships, including a multi-year deal with ServiceNow, underscoring its push to regain momentum in the rapidly evolving enterprise AI market.
text:
OpenAI is intensifying its global expansion and enterprise focus as chief executive Sam Altman prepares for a planned visit to India in mid-February, coinciding with the India AI Impact Summit 2026 in New Delhi. While Altman is not listed as a formal speaker, OpenAI is expected to host closed-door meetings and a private industry event during summit week, engaging investors, enterprise customers, and policymakers. The visit comes as India emerges as one of OpenAI’s largest user markets for ChatGPT and a strategic priority for enterprise adoption, regulatory engagement, and potential future infrastructure expansion amid growing competition from rivals including Google and Anthropic.

Separately, OpenAI has reorganized its leadership to strengthen enterprise sales, appointing Barret Zoph to lead global efforts to sell AI to business customers. Zoph, a former OpenAI vice president who recently returned after a stint at Thinking Machine Labs, takes on the role as enterprise AI adoption becomes a central priority for 2026. The move follows growing pressure from competitors gaining ground in enterprise large language model usage. OpenAI has also expanded partnerships, including a multi-year deal with ServiceNow, underscoring its push to regain momentum in the rapidly evolving enterprise AI market.

description:

TrendForce analyst Frank Kung said Nvidia's GB300 platform is on track to anchor most global AI data centers in 2026, accounting for an estimated 70% to 80% of worldwide AI server rack shipments.
Data Centers Remain Core Growth Driver Counterpoint also highlighted AMD's data center segment as its primary growth engine.

AMD Price Action: Advanced Micro Devices shares were up 3.73% at $263.20 at the time of publication on Friday.
text:
Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (NASDAQ:AMD) stock rose on Friday as investors assessed the company's artificial intelligence prospects in both data centers and personal computers, even as Nvidia Corp. (NASDAQ:NVDA) continues to dominate next-generation AI infrastructure.

TrendForce analyst Frank Kung said Nvidia's GB300 platform is on track to anchor most global AI data centers in 2026, accounting for an estimated 70% to 80% of worldwide AI server rack shipments.

AMD continues to feature prominently in the competitive landscape with its MI400 accelerators, which analysts expect to be shipped alongside Nvidia systems as aggregate AI server volumes increase.

AMD Targets Mass-Market AI PCs After CES 2026

AMD is positioning itself for the next phase of AI-driven growth by pushing artificial intelligence into mainstream PCs, while relying on its data center business for longer-term momentum, according to Counterpoint Research. The company used CES 2026 to pivot from proof-of-concept demos to mass-market execution, aiming to scale AI features across affordable consumer and commercial PCs, as per the firm.

Major manufacturers, including Dell Technologies Inc. (NYSE:DELL) and HP Inc. (NYSE:HPQ), plan to launch AMD-powered AI PCs in early 2026, with entry-level pricing starting at around $499. Counterpoint noted that AMD is emphasizing practical use cases such as productivity, gaming, and creative workloads, a strategy that could help spark a new PC upgrade cycle, particularly in desktops.

Data Centers Remain Core Growth Driver

Counterpoint also highlighted AMD's data center segment as its primary growth engine. Strong hyperscaler demand, tight supply conditions, and rising server CPU adoption are expected to support earnings. At the same time, platform initiatives like Helios could further strengthen AMD's role in AI infrastructure without directly displacing Nvidia.

AMD shares were largely unaffected by Intel Corp.'s (NASDAQ:INTC) quarterly results, which sent Intel stock lower. Intel reported fourth-quarter revenue of $13.67 billion, beating estimates of $13.37 billion, while adjusted earnings of 15 cents per share exceeded expectations. However, revenue declined 4% year over year, and the company guided to breakeven earnings in the first quarter.

AMD Price Action: Advanced Micro Devices shares were up 3.73% at $263.20 at the time of publication on Friday. The stock is trading near its 52-week high of $267.07, according to Benzinga Pro data.
